2008/8/8 Alex Ruiz <alruiz15@...>:
> ...note that GuiTask
> uses invokeAndWait instead of invokeLater. IMHO, most
> of the time in your test you need to wait for an
> action to be executed in the EDT before you can
> continue the execution of your test.

Note, however, that in many cases merely using invokeAndWait is not
enough because calling a Swing component can add other events to the
queue.  So, although invokeAndWait will block until the initial method
call is complete, the other events will not have been processed by the
time invokeAndWait returns, and the entire behaviour being tested will
not yet have been completed.  This can make the test go out of synch
with the Swing code: the test will fail may fail intermittently or
succeed when it should fail.

To unit test an object that calls invokeLater, I've found it easiest
to separate the threading concerns from the logic I want to test.
I've implemented a java.util.Executor that delegates to the Swing
invokeLater method. I then pass that Executor it to any object that
needs to call invokeLater and removed all direct calls to invokeLater.
 I can then easily unit test the behaviour of those objects with a
mock Executor or with a deterministic executor that captures tasks and
runs them on the test thread.

JMock  2.5.0 provides a DeterministicExecutor in the
org.jmock.lib.concurrent package.

A more detailed description of this technique is at
http://www.jmock.org/threads.html
